Was that the media's fault for focusing on the wrong things or the candidate's fault for not finding ways to get her message through?
Steve, you know, I'd say that Monday morning quarterbacking's always easy to do.

And what I've said already publicly - and I'll repeat - there is something about our current political ecosystem - and we're all a part of it - the parties, the candidates, the media, the voters - that leads us to avoid going deep into the issues that are really going to affect people's day-to-day lives.
You talked about this with the comedian Trevor Noah the other day.
And you said a number of things in a row.
You observed that there had been contacts between members of Mr. Trump's staff and Russian officials.
You noted that Trump benefited from the hacks.
Your spokesman, Josh Earnest, has gone on to say this week that it's obvious that Trump knew what was going on.
To what extent are you suggesting some kind of cooperation between the president-elect and Russian officials here?
I'm not suggesting cooperation at all.
Keep in mind that those statements were in the context of everyone now acting surprised by the CIA assessment that this was done purposely to improve Trump's chances.
And my only point was, that shouldn't be treated as a blockbuster (laughter) because that was the worst kept secret in this town.
Everybody understood that.
It was reported on.
Now, the president did not say exactly what he thinks Russian President Vladimir Putin's motives were.
He's waiting for a formal report from intelligence agencies.
But he notes that the United States publicly blamed Russia for the hacks back in October, and he says Trump's campaign understood the hacks were helping him.

When you combine that with the fact that the president-elect has been very honest about his admiration for Putin and that he hopes to forge a more cooperative relationship with him and focus on the threat of Islamic terrorism, then my only point was we shouldn't now suddenly act as if this is a huge revelation.
Is it necessary for the security of the United States that Russia pay some price for doing this - if, as they said - as you said, they did it.
I think there is no doubt that when any foreign government tries to impact the integrity of our elections that we need to take action - and we will - at a time in place of our own choosing.
Some of it may be explicit and publicized.
Some of it may not be.
But Mr. Putin is well aware of my feelings about this because I spoke to him directly about it.
And there is a - among the big powers, there has been a traditional understanding of - that everybody's trying to gather intelligence on everybody else.

It's no secret that Russian intelligence officers or Chinese or, for that matter, Israeli or British or other intelligence agencies - that their job is to get insight into the workings of other countries that they're not reading in the newspapers every day.
There's a difference between that and the kind of malicious cyberattacks that steal trade secrets or engage in industrial espionage, something that we've seen the Chinese do.
And there's a difference between that and activating intelligence in a way that's designed to influence elections.
So we have been working hard to make sure that what we do is proportional, that what we do is meaningful.

One of the things that we're going to have to do over the next decade is to ultimately arrive at some rules of what is a new game, and that is the way in which traditional propaganda and traditional covert influence efforts are being turbocharged by the internet and by the cyberworld.
If whatever response you take is not completed by January 20, do you have any reason to have confidence that President Trump will continue it?
My view is that this is not a partisan issue.
And part of what we should be doing is to try to take it out of election season and move it into governing season.
The president knows that's tricky, though, since surveys show some Republican voters have warmed to Putin as Trump has campaigned.
Think about that.
Over a third (laughter) of Republican voters think Putin's a good guy.

This is somebody - the former head of the KGB who is responsible for crushing democracy in Russia, muzzling the press, throwing political dissidents in jail, countering American efforts to expand freedom at every turn, is currently making decisions that's leading to a slaughter in Syria.
And a big chunk of the Republican Party, which prided itself during the Reagan era and for decades that followed as being the bulwark against Russian influence, now suddenly is embracing him.
It sounds like you hope any response would continue after January 20.
But do you have any reason to know that it would?
Well, I - you know, I can't...
Is that - yeah...
...Look into my crystal ball.
And that's probably a question better directed to the president-elect.
I can say that I've had a conversation with the president-elect about our foreign policy generally.
And Obama says he told Trump about something he believes the next president must preserve.
Even our adversaries generally respect our adherence to rule of law, our transparency, our openness.

And if we start losing that - if other countries start saying that, well, America doesn't care about these issues or it's just a might-makes-right environment and we're not speaking out on behalf of our values and demonstrating our values, then America's going to be significantly weakened.

If it were cheap, we'd all be doing it.
The fact is that it's costly, it's paradigm shifting.
In some cases, as you see with alternate fuels, they're difficult to find.

So I want to move on to a listener letter, Julianne.
We've got Tekiya Meramin(ph).
She writes: This one is for Dr. Malveaux.
I have read every money book out there.
They all say I need to diversify the types of loans and credit cards I have in order to boost my FICO score.
The problem is my score is so low I don't qualify for the credit cards and loans needed to diversify.
And the bills I pay on time regularly - rent, cable, cell phone, car insurance - do nothing to boost my score.
What can I do to get my FICO score higher?
Well, I'd encourage your reader, first of all, to - tell your listener to continue to pay the bills she does have on time.
She may want to look at a secured credit card, which would be a card where she uses some of her savings to secure a card, let's say $1,000, charge something on it then pay it back in a timely way.
That's one of the ways.
There's a great book online, Farai, if you go on to www.myFICO.com, F - my F-I-C-O.com.
They've actually got a little booklet there that explains how - what your FICO score is and how you can get it up.

She's probably going to have to do something drastic because if she's basically saying I'm spending everything I earn on my regular bills, and I see no way to boost my credit - until she has credit, she can't boost her credit score.
One of the components of the FICO score actually is the - your credit history.
In other words, how long you've had credit.
So, if she went out to get a credit card tomorrow, that, quite frankly, would not help her at all; it might help her in a year.
Now, explain what FICO is.
Okay, FICO Stands for Fair Isaac, something, but Fair Isaac Credit Organization, something like that.
They - the score ranges from 300 to 850, the higher the score, the better your credit.
For a consumer looking at it - if you want to get a loan, someone with a score of 300 might be offered a loan at 10 percent while someone with a score of 850 might be offered a loan at 2 percent.
So, the better your credit, the lower the risk you are.
I can't tell you how they come up with these scores because they won't tell anyone.
But it's an algorithm that includes all kinds of things.
What kind of credit you have - but that's really a small part of it.
What kind of credit you have?
How - What's your credit history?
How new is your credit?
What's your payment history?
I mean, the one thing I would implore every listener is to pay your bills on time.
If you don't pay...
Now.
let me ask you, Julianne.
If you have things like bounced checks, does that also affect your score?
It doesn't necessarily affect your FICO score, although your bank can report you.
And if you've got a bounced check to your credit card - oh yes, believe me - that will affect your score.
The other two things, Farai, that affect your score are, how much money you owe, basically, the proportion between what you owe and how much available credit you have.
So, if you've got a credit card with a $10,000 limit on it, and you're up to $9,000, they're going to look at your record and say, oh, this woman looks pretty overextended.
On the other hand, a $10,000 line of credit with a $2,000 debt looks a lot better.
And then how long you've had every credit card.
So, lots of times, credit counselors will advise people to cancel credit cards, but you don't want to cancel old ones.
If you've had a credit card for a long time and you've been pretty prompt with it, don't cancel that one.
Cancel the new one.
And don't apply for new cards if you've got some challenges with your FICO score unless you're trying to establish credit.
But, you know, these companies will send you cards and they'll say, we've got a great deal here for you.
Literally, every little thing you do regarding your credit will affect your FICO score.
Good scores are considered 700 and above, and if you've got a score below 600, you've got a lot of trouble.
All right.
Well, Julianne, thank you so much.
Thank you.
